thread.title: Fast and furious: What happened in the U.S. Treasury market?
thread.title_full: Fast and furious: What happened in the U.S. Treasury market? - MarketWatch

author: By     Elliot Blair Smith
title: Fast and furious: What happened in the U.S. Treasury market?
text:
Where did the liquidity go on Oct. 15? High-frequency trading firms are recruiting traders and technologist with offers of well-paying jobs that come with daily catered lunches, in-chair massages and complementary entertainment tickets. If you have strong quantitative skills—and a very cool, casual wardrobe—and if you speak a foreign language, like Python, that’s a plus.
But when you get to the interview, be sure to ask your prospective boss what happened in the U.S. Treasuries market on Oct. 15, 2014. Because if these amazingly smart professionals can’t answer the question satisfactorily, then you might want think twice about a business that substitutes speed for judgment, at great risk to all of us.
Last month, U.S. financial regulators released preliminary “findings” that they have absolutely no idea of what triggered one of the most volatile trading days in recent history , rivaling the volume and whipsaw prices of three years earlier, when Standard & Poor’s unexpectedly downgraded the federal government’s credit rating.
Also see: Why the bond market went bananas one day
This follows the May 2010 flash crash in the U.S. stock market, in which a high-frequency trader was criminally implicated by American authorities, as well as an exchange-system glitch that coincided with Facebook’s May 2012 Facebook initial public offering, and a mistake involving a Knight Capital order-routing system in August 2012.
Getting to the bottom of what happened in the U.S. Treasury market is essential because it is among the world’s biggest, and should be all but immune from unexpected blips.
The size of this investment has nearly tripled to $12.6 trillion from $4.3 trillion at the outset of the financial crisis in June 2007. It’s also among the most broadly owned. Setting aside the Federal Reserve’s portfolio of Treasury securities, mutual funds nearly doubled their share to 8.2% as of March, compared with less than 4.5% before the crisis.
The biggest investors, of course, are foreigners—including central banks and sovereign wealth funds—which account for 47.3% of the market.
Treasury securities perform a variety of essential functions, from providing short-term liquidity as a cash equivalent, to stable long-term investments. But the composition of the market increasingly has shifted away from traditional banks to so-called principal trading firms, or PTFs, that specialize in high-speed trading systems.
These electronic platforms rely principally on computer algorithms, rather than on individual human judgments, for trading decisions measured in thousandths of a second.
You know the playing field has changed when math PhD’s in business suits fight about the length of electrical cords connecting them to exchange data.
Here’s what’s known about Oct. 15: Levered selling positions in short term, interest-rate futures contracts, such as Eurodollars, had reached a record level at the end of September. But traders were unwinding these “short” positions, as U.S. rates moved lower, in the opposite direction of the bets. Such deleveraging, while gradual, is thought to have put downward pressure on Treasury yields.
